question: Tuberculosis of spine best diagnostic modality is:

question: Which of the following is false about HIV related ahritis?
exp: HIV related ahritis: 1. Presents as an asymmetric oligo ahritis (MC), symmetrical polyahritis or as a monoahritis. 2. Males > Females 3. Most common joint effected: knee 4. question: Apparent lengthening of limb is seen in which TB hip stage of?
exp: TUBERCULOSIS OF HIP: INITIAL FOCUS IN ACETABULUM (MOST COMMON SITE) AND FEMUR (BABCOCK'S TRIANGLE) staging of T. B hip is given in treasure attached Stages of TB ahritis: Hip 1. Stage of synovitis: flexion, abduction, external rotation - apparent lengthening 2. Stage of early ahritis: flexion, adduction, internal rotation - apparent shoening (<1cm) 3. Stage of late ahritis: flexion, adduction, internal rotation - true shoening (>1cm) 4. Stage of subluxation (wandering acetabulum): pestle and moar deformity (large acetabulum and small head of femur) 5. Stage of fibrous ankylosis.

question: A 35-year-old lady with chronic backache. On X-ray she had a D12 collapse. But interveebral disc space is maintained. All are possible except:
exp: Characteristic radiological feature of Pott's spine Obliteration of disk space with destruction of two adjacent veebrae. Osteoporosis: Cod fish appearance is seen in which the disc bulges into the nearby veebral bodies and the disc becomes biconvex. Multiple myeloma: Wedge collapse of the veebra is seen and most of the time involving more than one veebra, commonly in the thoracic spine. Metastasis: Well circumscribed. Can be sclerotic e. g prostrate; osteolytic e. g. renal and thyroid or mixed e. g. breast and lung

question: A patient of tubercular synovitis of hip joint was staed on ATT and skin traction was applied, no improvement is seen after prolonged chemotherapy. What will be the next best step?
exp: Tuberculous synovitis Uncommon even in countries where tuberculosis is still rife. Diagnosis should be considered in patients with chronic synovitis once the alternatives such as rheumatoid disease have been excluded, it can be confirmed by synol biopsy. Rx First line - Chemotherapy and traction No relief - Joint open by posterior approach, joint debridement and Synovectomy done
opc: Continue the same for a period of 12 months

question: Arrange the following condition according to the worsening stages in TULI's clinical staging a-Paraplegia in extension b- ankle clonus present, extensor plantar response, no sensory deficit c- no sensory deficit, motor deficit, ambulatory with suppo d-Paraplegia in flexion
exp: Tuli's clinical staging is used for assessment of severity and progression of neural deficit Stage 1: Patient unaware of neural deficit, physician detects plantar extensor and/or ankle clonus. Stage 2: Patient aware of deficit but manages to walk with suppo, clumsiness of gait. Stage 3: Paralysis in extension, sensory deficit less than 50% Stage 4: III + flexor spasm/ paralysis in flexion/ flaccid/ sensory deficit more than 50%/ sphincters involved
